post.description: The bootstrap sub-command is used to download and extract releases and templates for use with Bastille containers. A valid release is needed before containers can be created. Templates are optional but are managed in the same manner.
Clone/duplicate an existing jail to a new jail.
Execute commands inside targeted jail(s).
Get, set or remove properties from targeted jail(s).
Launch a login shell into the jail. Default is password- less root login.
Convert a thin jail to a thick jail. Convert a thick jail to a custom release.
Copy files from host to jail(s).
Create a jail uning any available bootstrapped release. To create a jail, simply provide a name, bootstrapped release, and IP address.
Destroy jails or releases.
Edit jail config files.
This command will update the contents of /etc inside a jail. It should be run after a jail upgrade.
Exporting a container creates an archive or image that can be sent to a different machine to be imported later. These exported archives can be used as container backups.
This command runs htop in the targeted jail. Requires htop to be installed in the jail.
Import a jail backup image or archive.
Copy files from jail to jail(s).
Set resourse limits for targeted jail(s).
List jails, ports, releases, templates, logs, limits, exports and imports and much more managed by bastille.
The migrate sub-command allows migrating the targeted jail(s) to another remote system.
To mount storage within the container use bastille mount.
Add or remove interfaces to existing jails.
Manage binary packages inside jails.
This command allows copying files from jail to host.
Bastille rdr allows you to configure dynamic rdr rules for your containers without modifying pf.conf.
Rename a jail.
Restart jail(s).
The service sub-command allows for managing services within jails. This allows you to start, stop, restart, and otherwise interact with services running inside the jail(s).

The setup sub-command attempts to automatically configure a host system for Bastille jails. This allows you to configure networking, firewall, storage, vnet and bridge options for a Bastille host with one command.
Start jail(s).
Stop jail(s).
The sysrc sub-command allows for safely editing system configuration files. In jail terms, this allows us to toggle on/off services and options at startup.
The tags sub-command adds, removes or lists arbitrary tags on your jail(s).
Apply file templates to targeted container(s).
This command runs top in the targeted jail.
Unmount storage from jail(s).
The update command targets a release or a thick jail. Because thin jails are based on a release, when the release is updated all the thin jails are automatically updated as well.
The upgrade command targets a thick or thin jail. Thin jails will be updated by changing the release mount point that it is based on. Thick jails will be upgraded normally.

This command scans a bootstrapped release or template and validates that everything looks in order. This is not a 100% comprehensive check, but it compares the release or template against a “known good” index.
Manage ZFS properties, create, destroy and rollback snapshots, jail and unjail datasets (ZFS only), and check ZFS usage for targeted jail(s).
